page.title: 11Surface Water:Chilterns.
page.content: There is not much surface water in our area because of the underlying chalk of the{Chiltern Hills. The{River Wye}passes through the south of the area on its way to the{River {Thames}at{Bourne End.}The{Wye}has been channelled into a concrete duct in places. Although it once supplied power to the local paper mills. It is now a shallow, slow flowing stream less than 4m wide. The{Back Stream,}which was formerly a {mill stream,}and now acts as an overflow from the{Dyke,}flows through the{Lagoon}which is part of the{sewage {works.}It passes close to the{river {Wye.}The{Back Stream}and{Lagoon}are very interesting because each have a natural spring emerging from the bedrock and coming to the surface of the water.
